title: How AI is Being Used During the Coronavirus

data.content: The Duality of Using AI in an Ethical & Human-Centric Way
In the times of crisis and disaster management of 2020, how did innovative technologies such as AI hold up?

There were many real world examples of machine learning helping with diagnosing COVID-19 infections, predicting the inception and spread of the virus or speeding up drug research. However among many wins, there was hesitation and mental barrier to using AI and experimenting during this time of critical decision making.

Secondly, was the use of AI ethical and conscious during this pandemic? Did we anonymize data, limit the collection of personal information, maintain individual’s right to privacy and eliminate biases from the equation?

This article will give you a brief overview of use cases of Artificial Intelligence to help tackle the challenges arising out of this pandemic, as well as the key factors to keep in mind to responsibly use this technology for the public good while reducing the privacy concerns of citizens across different geographies.
Leveraging AI and Data during COVID-19
AI can be used for 3 types of use cases primarily — Automation, Detection, Forecasting/Prediction.
A few ways AI can be used to tackle challenges during this global health crisis:
Let’s get on with each of these use cases in detail!
Detection, Analysis & Insights

First and foremost, AI can be used to conduct contextualized text analysis on news, blogs, forums, basically all the content that there is on the internet relating to the pandemic and beyond (customer behavior, industries affected etc.), to provide contextualized insights for different usecases, or in many cases also spot fake news, spam or illicit content.
AI can also find important correlations between many different data points, such as cases identified and the movement patterns of the people who are living in the areas most affected by the virus.
This text analysis and pattern detection is being used by many companies and researchers around the globe to get the most accurate picture of unique (non-redundant) information in one place.

Palantir, silicon valley’s favourite data intelligence company is providing COVID-19 tracking software to CDC and NHS to enable disparate data to be integrated, cleaned, and harmonised in order to develop the single source of truth that will support decision-making.
Forecasting & Pattern detection

BlueDot is a Canadian company that has an artificial intelligence platform that tracks infectious diseases around the world. They were the first company in Dec 2019 to flag a cluster of “unusual pneumonia” cases happening around a market in Wuhan, China.

The AI looks at statements from health organizations, commercial flights, livestock health reports, climate data from satellites, and news reports to detect patterns and forecast the potential spread of infectious diseases across the world and notify the relevant health authorities.
Automation
An AI system developed by Chinese tech giant Baidu uses cameras equipped with computer vision and infrared sensors to predict people’s temperatures in public areas.
This kind of tech is critical to exponentially scale your operations in an automated fashion, instead of relying just on manual intervention and analysis.
Analysis & Diagnosis
Alibaba, the Chinese tech giant, has developed an AI system that can detect coronavirus in chest CT scans.
The AI was trained on data from 5,000 coronavirus cases and can perform the test in 20 seconds as opposed to the 15 minutes it takes a human expert to diagnose patients.
It can also tell the difference between coronavirus and ordinary viral pneumonia. The system is reportedly being adopted in 100 hospitals in China.
Computer Vision & Automation

Chinese firms are using drones and robots to perform contact-less delivery and to spray disinfectants in public areas to minimize the risk of cross-infection. Other robots are checking people for fever and other COVID-19 symptoms and dispensing free hand sanitizer foam and gel.

Inside hospitals, robots are delivering food and medicine to patients and disinfecting their rooms to obviate the need for the presence of nurses. Other robots are busy cooking rice without human supervision, reducing the number of staff required to run the facility.
In Seattle, doctors used a robot to communicate with and treat patients remotely to minimize exposure of medical staff to infected people.
Identification & Analysis
Drug Research
DeepMind, the AI research lab acquired by Google in 2014, recently declared that it has used deep learning to find new information about the structure of proteins associated with COVID-19.
This has helped in understanding more about this novel virus and speed up drug research.
Determine which patients need hospitalization
AI can also help with identifying which patients need hospitalization versus which patients can do with milder courses of action.
One of the most difficult clinical challenges currently is to understand which patient could do well at home, and which patient is likely to not survive no matter what therapy is offered.

AI can help identify uninfected individuals out in the community who are at risk for a severe course of illness. Health care organizations can then advise these people to exercise complete precautions for self-isolation.

One of the algorithms looked over data from 2 million patients to determine which among thousands of factors increase the risks of acquiring infections that lead to end-organ damage, such as respiratory failure. As with other research on coronavirus, the findings have flagged old age and chronic conditions as major risk factors for poor outcomes.

But the machine learning algorithm was also able to ferret out social risk factors, including long commutes, living in dense residential areas such as college dorms, attending public events and shopping in person.
There are hundreds of other use-cases of AI out there — all of them require data to analyze, forecast, predict, automate, which brings me to my next point —
Responsible use of AI

We know that there is an immense amount of positive power and potential in AI. It can help those embroiled in fighting this battle to slow the spread of this debilitating disease. It can help save lives.

But we must stay vigilant and commit to the safe, ethical and responsible use of AI — focus on compliance and the systemic shifts in the norms of doing business. It is essential that, even in times of this crisis, we remain conscience of the duality of AI and strive to advance AI for good.

Now governments around the world are demanding extraordinary new surveillance powers to fight the virus. And hence we need close scrutiny of these new relationships that are forming between governments and private companies during this pandemic.
I’ve two examples of companies/organizations who are trying to create human centric frameworks to protect user privacy while attempting to use data for the common good.

Apple has indicated that it is collecting information only on how people are using its screening tool — not the answers they provide — and that the information will not identify them. Apple will apparently retain information collected from its screening tool only long enough to finish its project, and will not use it for advertising.

Similarly, MIT has teamed up with Facebook, Mayo Clinic, and other organizations to create an app that collects information using a technique known as differential privacy, a way of publicly sharing information that is gleaned from a data set without identifying the individuals whose activities are represented in that data set.
Going forward
We saw how AI is helping fight coronavirus through targeted usecases in the healthcare, research, government and public health space. However, the road is still a work in progress —
#1 AI + data-mining techniques in drug discovery
AI cannot alone save us from the pandemic. Drug discovery researchers are of the opinion —

Instead, AI can complement other data mining techniques to help sift through this overload of information and to spot those encouraging trends.Hence yes AI can be used for analysis and automation to a certain degree, but it still has to reach its potential in concrete usecases such as drug discovery.
#2 Rethink how data is stored and shared; fairness and transparency
This pandemic can also help us to rethink how data is stored and shared, measures we need to take to strike that balance between privacy and value.

Strong measures would be taken to help solve fairness, transparency ad explainability challenges arising out of using artificial intelligence in our daily workflows and to solve tangible customer challenges.
#3 AI is the new norm

And definitely AI is going to be part of the new norm — whether it’s helping us in our day to day jobs of automatically ordering groceries, doing self-examinations or getting diagnosis via an algorithm, getting recommendations for our finances or for business scenario planning.
